Name: Dublin Castle

Storys.Title: Medieval Tower
Storys.ContentText:
Also Known as the Wardrobe Tower, Gunner’s Tower or Record Tower

The Medieval Tower is one of the oldest, most intact and most important parts of the city of Dublin to survive today. Dating from 1204-28, it was largely constructed during the reign of Henry III (1207–72), King of England and Lord of Ireland. Its walls are up to 4.8 metres thick.

In 1811 the tower was converted to hold state papers, at which time it was revamped to complement the new Chapel Royal being constructed next to it. The height of the tower was raised and its parapet was capped with new masonry battlements.

Like all the early buildings of the Castle, it has had a variety of functions over the centuries. In its early use as the king’s Wardrobe Tower, armour, clothes and the king’s treasure were stored there.

Storys.Title: King John
Storys.ContentText:
King John commands the building of a castle in Dublin to protect his treasure and to act as a centre of English power in Ireland.

It remained a symbol of this power until the handover to Michael Collins, Sinn Fein and the Provisional Government was finally achieved in 1922 following the Easter Rising.

Storys.Title: The Escape
Storys.ContentText: Red Hugh escapes from Dublin Castle.

Storys.Title: The Handover
Storys.ContentText:
The birth of the Irish Free State. 

Dublin Castle symbol and citadel of British Rule for centuries surrenders to Sinn Fein Provisional Government. 

The official entry was singularly undramatic - though a moment that will live forever in Irish minds.

Storys.Title: The Waiter
Storys.ContentText: Getting ready for a grand dinner and an important visit.

Storys.Title: The Hospital
Storys.ContentText:
During WWI, these State Apartments were turned into a hospital to care for the wounded.

What a place to recover!

Storys.Title: A Place of Spectacle
Storys.ContentText:
The power of image.

The Upper Courtyard has always been a place for people to gather, from ladies and gents promenading in their finery, to military parade and visits from royalty.

Storys.Title: The Body
Storys.ContentText:
THE SKELETON of a child dating back to the early Viking period has been discovered during an archaeological dig in Dublin. 

It was discovered during excavations at the sight near the original Dubh Linn, which translates as black pool and served as the origins for the name Dublin. 

The largely intact skeleton was found at the point just before the point where the River Poddle flows into the Dubh Linn, close to the River Liffey.
